oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Jerry Zolten Phone Interview of Pete Seeger - 1974 - Tape 1
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of a phone interview between Pete Seeger (singer/social activist) and Jerry Zolten (host/writer/producer). The tape is the first of two from an unidentified date in 1974.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jerry Zolten; Pete Seeger
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Pete Seeger and Jerry Zolten discuss Reprints From People's Songs; additionally, Seeger describes the type of man Irwin Silber is -- (06:46) Seeger describes how the new songs he performs are about the working-class struggles, and Seeger describes what a 'hootenanny' is -- (11:11) Zolten a Seeger describe what "Pretty Boy Floyd," among other songs, past controversies were -- (13:28) Zolten recalls the first time he heard Seeger's name associated to communism; additionally, Seeger reflects on the various communist studies he performed -- (22:45) Seeger and Zolten reflect on the amount of musicians who perform without proper musical knowledge -- (25:31) Seeger admits that his work with the Hudson River has led to health issues -- (27:13) Zolten inquires as to how he may communicate with Seeger; as well as, both reflect on the various formats of audio exchange
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Zolten, Jerry; Seeger, Pete, 1919-2014;
